messages.message:
Request from Blend [i anticipate we might get questions like this from others” @Heymian @achao

Q: “I’m an admin in Instabase. How can I remove a user from having access to Instabase”
A: ah interesting — we don’t have a concept of actually removing the user completely. We can think of adding a feature through the UI which enables an admin to disable a user’s access to Instabase

got it, yeah, deleting users has been on the todo list for a while now. might be worth doing soon. Asana task is here in case anyone wants to add info to it: https://app.asana.com/0/869205164872194/1114432324033074
Very soon as I've given some access to users for temporary purposes and we should probably give them the boot eventually
We do have a feature to disable a user account.
How would one do such a thing
I understand that it is different from deleting an account.
There is a field in users table.
i think disabling a user account is a great way to go — i just realized there’s something like “is_verified”: false or something right?
Yeah David
or “is_approved” perhaps
i think it’s `is_active`
one addition though when we create the UI is, we should probably strip the user of all existing permissions from all ACL tables
right, i was going to say. just flipping that bit isn’t enough
Heymian, I don't think we use is_active anywhere.
we’d have to remove then from all orgs, teams, acl lists as well
yeah because we don’t currently support “deletion” or “deactivating”
so we’ve never flipped that bit before

There are four fields:
is_admin
is_active: not used anywhere
is_verified: when the email address is verified
is_approved: when they are not on the waitlist
I’m :+1: on deactivation, deletion has some negative effects like reuse of usernames which I dont think we’ll want
Mark is_approved to False and the user goes onto a waitlist
Kk will test on your account real fast :wink:
Having said all this, I think we should change our software such that we start using `is_active` flag.
yeah, poor verbiage. deletion = deactivation = flip `is_active` and purge connection to all our other tables.
yeah we don’t even delete repos atm, we just “hide” it. So that will also need to happen when we actually purge.
If we do go the purge route, we might want to take all that was purged, compress it, and save it to some other table… just thinking about auditability over time
One would want to be guaranteed the ability to go back and know that UID `foo` was a deleted user with information `xyz`
Let’s chat about purge route in details later.  It is a can of worms with regards to compliance
(sort of like creating a Google Takeout archihve and then stashing it somewhere before teh actual deletion)
